author: @arenashawn772
text: I had a rather interesting policy discussion with a friend right before watching this video about p-value, about some tests being run to decide if certain public health measures should be put into place. The test for effectiveness for the said measures appear to be positive but the p value ended up being slightly higher than 0.05 and therefore ‚Äúbased on statistical knowledge‚Äù the measures to be carried out was rejected and never ended up being put into place.  After watching the last segments of your video, I feel the sadness of the decision being made largely based on scientific dogma instead of real scientific understanding‚Ä¶ Like you have pointed out, 0.05 is a chosen value not a golden standard. If little statistical random chance of the null hypothesis being true would lead to grave consequences, it should be lowered further. In the case for the said public health measure, it would bring significant benefits and the cost of carrying it out is not huge, so a slightly higher than 0.05 p-value should not have stood in the way of a possibly very true and positive effect had it been carried out‚Ä¶ Sigh.  I digress and rant‚Ä¶ Thanks for another great episode. ‚ù§

author: @nr7507
text: At 6:55, Depending on the null hypothesis that: Both the groups were given the same drug A but due to some variation in the attributes we could get that 1 percent of the time that they are different (and by different I refer to the different drugs but not a difference in the attributes of people on whom we test), so hence the conclusion that getting a value lower than or equal to the p value is False positive.  So essentially it depends on what we formulate as our Null Hypothesis that defines if p value lower than or greater than threshold that determines false positive or is it always the case? Because what if they were indeed different drugs(and say this was our hypothesis) and we got a p value smaller than 0.01, then would that not signify to NOT be false positives? I am slightly new to this and it is a little confusing.

author: @SaidakbarP
text: Hi Josh, thanks again! Is my interpretation correct: In this drug A and B example, our hypothesis test would be as follows: H0: both drugs are the same H1: they are different Result: p=0.04 means the probability of both being the same is 4% while probability they are different is 96%.  If our rejection value is p<0.05, then we can reject the null hypothesis that they are the same and conclude these drugs are different at least for our given confidence interval.

author: @avocadotoast8557
text: So correct me if I‚Äôm wrong. This is what I understood: the p-value helps to see if you have a fake positive or a true result. It also tells us if there is a random chance of whatever it is in the sample. If for example in the two groups we have a huge difference between them then there is not random chance but if the differences between them is not that big then we have to use the p-value to determine whether or not there is a random chance. And the p-value that is mostly used to see if the result is true or not, is that it has to be less that 0.05.

author: @Ihsan_almohsin
text: p value < 0.05  The smaller the p-value, the stronger the evidence that you should reject the null hypothesis. It indicates strong evidence against the null hypothesis,  as there is less than a 5% probability the null is correct (and the results are random).  Therefore, we reject the null hypothesis, and accept the alternative hypothesis.   p value > 0.05  This means we retain the null hypothesis and reject the alternative hypothesis.  You should note that you cannot accept the null hypothesis, we can only reject the null or fail to reject it.

author: @Happy.Traveller
text: I hate statistics with a passion, it never makes any sense and is always counterintuitive. You might be good at explaining, but the explanation makes no sense to me. Could you shed some light for me please:  The excuses at regarding why a drug failed or worked, makes zero sense to me in a real world application. If you say "oh maybe the drug works but was mislabelled" or "one drug is actually a placebo" well then: In the real world experiment you would control all the variables and for example have made sure not to mislabel the item, and someone, even in a double blind study, would  know at some point whether it is a placebo or not.  No matter how many times you repeat something, all those excuses still stand and are possible and valid. Placebo power can be great and it is possible to find a large group of easily impressionable or gullible people for whom a placebo works for a large majority of. Similarly, if we are talking about unlikely events like "Maybe the drug was mislabelled", then if 1 pill was mislabelled then the entire batch of a million pills were also mislabelled, causing everyone who took it to have taken a mislabelled drug. So then you'd have 1 million people if each took 1 MISLABELLED pill, and were cured/not cured then your conclusion would still be wrong.

author: @alimehdizadeh2715
text: Those who wonder how the p-value was calculated for the drug examples: Take a=(took drug A and cured)=73, b=(took drug B and cured)=59, c=(took drug A and not cured)=125, d=(took drug B and bot cured)=131.  Null-hypothesis: Drugs A and B are no different (produce the same effect). p-value=(a+b)!(c+d)!(a+c)!(b+d)!  /  (a!b!c!d!n!) = (132!*256!*198!*190!)/(73!*59!*125!*131!*388!) = 0.24

text: P values quantity that there is a difference between drug A and B, but not HOW MUCH different !!!! Could be a small difference or a HUGE difference. All that matters is there is a A difference, regardless of how big or small it is!!

author: @ojd3708
text: P value does not indicate difference size between samples. You can have a P value of 0.24 between 2 drugs and still have a difference of 8 percent and still not statistically significant. Then you can have a P value of less than 0.05 ( 5 times out of 100 null hypothesis is valid) with less than  1 percent difference samples

author: @jossricketts4452
text: I appreciate your videos, especially the one about how p-value is calculated. But I'm still confused (probably, because other sources are also so obtuse about these things). So, and tell me if I'm wrong, there's Type 1 and Type 2 errors with their probabilities (with Type 1 being a significance level Alpha, which we set ourselves, say, Alpha = 0.05). Then there is p-value, which shows a probability that if H0 is true this is a probability of getting this data set or more extreme one.  So, in the end, we have probability Alpha for Type 1 errors, probability Beta for Type 2 errors and p-value, which we calculate for the selected H0. And the reason we use Alpha as a threshold for p-value is only because of convenience, because we don't want to bother with selecting two distinct significance levels  In any case, thank you for the content! Stay awesome!  P.S. Probably confused myself, trying to equate Type 1 or Type 2 to p-value. I don't know anymore

author: @stephenpuryear
text: Josh, this is really good! It covers that main points and helps us all focus on them. As a calibration person, I always find it interesting when I find situations in which we assume the perfection of the accuracy of our input data. This is not at all a criticism of your excellent effort, because if you tried to cover all considerations, you would never publish anything. This is what sank Charles Babbage. I appreciate how you pointed out the assumptions that are sometimes hidden in "hypothesis test". This is why juries find some people "not guilty" instead of "innocent".  There is an important sense in which those two things are not equivalent to each other. Thank you again!
